comments.text:
Believe it or not, there originally was a whole song in the dance number. 
The singing was to start right after the head-bang, but due to the 
discontent of the preview audience thinking it held up the pace of the film 
it ended up cut. However the motion picture soundtrack album includes the 
original prerecording which contains the missing 75% of the song.﻿

comments.author: SuperLC1010

comments.text:
They Majorly fucked up the Addams family lore with this movie. In this 
movie fester for some reason, is Gomez's brother. In the original series he 
was Gomez's uncle which means he's actually brother or brother in law to 
Grandama addams or *mama.* Thing is also odd in this movie as well 
considering in the original 1964 series thing wasnt just a hand, he was a 
full arm that extended out of different parts of the house. He was more of 
an interdenominational being rather than just a hand. The largest thing 
wrong with the movie was their depiction of Wednesday. Their daughter isnt 
so morose and cruel and miserable in the original series. This Wednesday in 
this movie just seems sadistic but not in an addams sense of sadism, she 
just seems cruel and mean which is something the addams family hates. And 
they make wednesday look older than pugsley which is wrong because pugsley 
is the older brother to wednesday. In short, this movie was a 
disappointment after the beauty of the original series. One last thing i 
have to mention Carrolyn Jones>Angelica houston Carrolyn is so much sexier 
than the current morticia﻿
comments.author: Mr. Reaper

comments.text:
The creator of the comic strips has said Gomez and Fester are brothers, I 
don't think it had been stated in the strips at the time of the tv series 
but since then and in almost every other media it's been but back to how 
it's supposed to be they're brothers.

So if you want to get technical it's the tv series that messed up the 
"lore". It's like someone complaining "why doesn't Batman have a red phone 
that connects directly to the commissioner, labeled pipes that slide to the 
batcave, dance or makes jokes" in the current films or comics.
comments.author: woollybully100

comments.text:

comments.author: Mr. Reaper

comments.text:
I'll basically address each point individually.

Fester, in all other media but the TV show, is Gomez' brother, typically 
older.

Thing was actually a whole person in the original comic, but some changes 
are for the better and I like the strangeness of him being basically a 
disembodied hand/forearm. I think conceptually they're basically the same 
thing so I think the difference in the show and movies is fine, for all we 
know it was intended Thing be a disembodied hand and the technology was 
simply out of grasp.

Wednesday was much more morbid and morose in the original comic than in the 
TV show (watch the cartoon, she's similar to the film version). I 
personally don't think she's overly sadistic in the movies, remember that 
basically her entire family is immune to damage, and most of her 
shenanigans are played for laughs rather than as acts of cruelty. I think 
the intention of the writers plays a big part of The Addams Family. 
Remember that at heart, they exist for comedic purposes, to compare and 
contrast with regular society. They could very easily be a lot darker, but 
rather they're done in a way that's designed to make us laugh.
comments.author: Fletchersaurus

comments.text:
Does this movie accurately represent the comics more? If so then why are 
there 2 alternate universes in the addams house?
comments.author: Mr. Reaper

comments.text:
Remember though, that this isn't based on the original sitcom, so comparing 
the two as if it is is an apples and oranges situation. The Addams Family 
was a comic by Charles Addams LOOOONG before the TV show.

comments.text:
I had such an obsession with this movie when I was a kid. My grandmother 
had the tape and whenever we'd go visit her, we watched it endlessly. It 
got to the point where my grandma would groan and say, "Oh God, not again!" 
lol. She tried to hide the tape repeatedly but we always found it. She even 
tried to hide it under some loose linoleum in her kitchen floor once. Until 
my dad and uncle went to re-do the floor one day and they found the tape. 
Grandma only had one word for that: "Dammit!" lmao.
comments.author: Kari  Chandler

comments.text:
Raul Julia was the best Gomez <3 Okay, so he wasn't the original. John 
Astin was brilliant, but the sit-com style of the show didn't give him much 
lee-way. Lets not even talk about Tim Curry (and usually I'm such a Tim 
Curry fan). Julia as Gomez was loveable, funny, sweet, hyper and 
immature... as well as having the latent dark-side that no other actor 
quite matched. Brilliant :')
